page.title: 12LIFE IN A RURAL COMMUNITY
page.content:
The people of Snelland accept the drawbacks of living in an outlying area with almost no public transport and none of the conveniences of a larger community. Parents and their children travel to other areas - Lincoln, Market Rasen or nearby villages to take part in such activities as swimming, sports, music or evening education.
When ambulance services were curtailed the villagers got together and drew up a rota for essential hospital visits. Those with cars also take neighbours shopping and on other necessary outings.
Villagers say that the disadvantages of isolation are fully compensated by the pleasures of living in the country away from the bustle of town life.
